trialDescription.title: The effect of free vitamin D-drops and tailor-made information on serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D among infants of immigrant origin in Oslo, Norway: a randomised controlled trial
trialDescription.acronym: Vitamin D-drops to infants with immigrant background
trialDescription.studyHypothesis:
The main objective of the trial is to study whether free supply of vitamin D drops to six weeks old infants of immigrants from Pakistan, Turkey and Somalia together with tailor-made information handouts improves vitamin D status at the age of three months in the intervention group compared to a control group. 

In addition, to study whether the information given also improves vitamin D status in the mothers in the intervention group compared to the control group.
trialDescription.plainEnglishSummary: Not provided at time of registration
trialDescription.primaryOutcome:
1. Change in 25-hydroxyvitamin D from baseline (six week of age) to follow-up (three months of age) in the intervention group compared to the control group, adjusted for baseline level of 25-hydroxyvitamin D 
2. Change in 25-hydroxyvitamin D from baseline to follow-up in the mothers in the intervention group compared to the mothers in the control group, adjusted for baseline level of 25-hydroxyvitamin D
trialDescription.secondaryOutcome: Is there any difference between the groups at a second follow-up at eight months of age
trialDescription.ethicsApproval: Approved by the ombudsman for privacy in research (ref: 200301024) on the 5th November 2003 and the Regional Committee for Medical Research Ethics (REK SÃ¸r) (ref: S-03196) on the 6th November 2003.

trialDesign.studyDesign: Open randomised controlled trial. Carried out at the Health Centre level. Health Centres were paired based on size. Randomisation was then carried out within each pair.

trialCentre.name: Institute of General Practice and Community Medicine

participants.inclusion:
1. Infants with Pakistani, Turkish or Somali background
2. Coming to routine consultation six weeks after birth in eight Health Centers in Oslo
participants.totalTarget: 48 participants (given randomization at the Health Center level)

intervention.description:
Intervention group: 
Provision of free vitamin D drops and instruction on how to administer it to their infants, including a tailored-made information brochure about vitamin D and its sources which have been translated to Urdu, Turkish and Somali. 

Control group: 
Usual care consisting of routine information about vitamin D and recommendation of use of vitamin D supplements, preferably cod liver oil.

results.publicationPlan: Not provided at time of registration

dataPolicies.dataPolicy: Not provided at time of registration

trialDescription.title: Proposal for pilot randomised controlled trial of pelvic floor exercises for premature ejaculation
trialDescription.studyHypothesis: Exploring the effectiveness of pelvic floor exercises for premature ejaculation.
trialDescription.plainEnglishSummary: Not provided at time of registration
trialDescription.primaryOutcome:
1. Subjects in both groups to be evaluated for PE initially, and at 3 months by completing a questionnaire.
2. Subjective & objective physiotherapy assessment to include digital anal measurements by clinician.
3. Assessment by Ros Wills, a physiotherapist who is blinded to the subject grouping.
trialDescription.secondaryOutcome: Not provided at time of registration
trialDescription.ethicsApproval: Not provided at time of registration

participants.inclusion: Not provided at time of registration
participants.totalTarget: 15 men in each arm of the trial, total 30
participants.exclusion: Not provided at time of registration

condition.description: Mental and Behavioural Disorders: Premature ejaculation (PE)

intervention.description: Treatment group of men with premature ejaculation (PE) receiving pelvic floor exercises and relaxation advice and a non-treatment control group of men with PE receiving only relaxation advice.

results.publicationPlan: Not provided at time of registration

dataPolicies.dataPolicy: Not provided at time of registration

trialDescription.title: A random controlled trial to compare the efficacy of a brief psycho-educational programme with standard care plus biblio-therapy for individuals with Bipolar Disorder at high risk for relapse.
trialDescription.studyHypothesis: To determine if a psycho-educational intervention is associated with significant clinical improvements
trialDescription.plainEnglishSummary: Not provided at time of registration
trialDescription.primaryOutcome: Time to first relapse as assessed by independent blind reviewer.
trialDescription.secondaryOutcome: Not provided at time of registration
trialDescription.ethicsApproval: Not provided at time of registration

participants.inclusion: Subjects with bipolar disorder in contact with 3CMHT in Lewisham catchment area, inpatient units at Ladywell or by direct recruitment by GPs.
participants.exclusion:
1. Subjects with co-morbid schizophrenia, schizo-affective disorder and psychosis 
2. Subjects with severe borderline or antisocial personality disorder
3. Subjects with primary substance abuse disorder 
4. Subjects suffering from an organic brain syndrome
5. Participants who currently meet DSM-IV criteria for mania, hypomania or mixed state (plus B-R> 15, &/or HRSD> 17). These patients could be admitted to the study in a later stage once they are euthymic, or mildly depressed or hypomaniac.
6. Subjects unable to read or write English 
7. Subjects unable to give informed consent

condition.description: Mental and Behavioural Disorders: Bipolar disorders

intervention.description:
Brief psycho-educational programme vs standard care plus biblio-therapy

Added 21 July 2008: trial discontinued in 2005

results.publicationPlan: Not provided at time of registration

dataPolicies.dataPolicy: Not provided at time of registration
